title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who were the first three sons of Israel listed in 1 Chronicles 2:1?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:1 lists the sons of Israel starting with Reuben, Simeon, and Levi as the first three.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 2:3, who were the three sons born to Judah from the daughter of Shua the Canaanitess?
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that Er, Onan, and Shelah were born unto Judah by the daughter of Shua the Canaanitess.

questions.question: What was the fate of Er, the firstborn of Judah, according to 1 Chronicles 2:3?
options: He was slain by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He was slain by the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse explains Er was evil in the sight of the LORD and the LORD slew him.

questions.question: Who were the sons of Pharez as listed in 1 Chronicles 2:5?
questions.explanation: Verse 5 states that the sons of Pharez were Hezron and Hamul.

questions.question: How many sons did Zerah have according to 1 Chronicles 2:6?
questions.explanation: The verse lists Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara as the five sons of Zerah.

questions.question: Who was called 'the troubler of Israel' in 1 Chronicles 2:7?
questions.explanation: Verse 7 states that Achar, son of Carmi, was the troubler of Israel.

questions.question: Who was the father of Boaz according to 1 Chronicles 2:11?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:11 says Nahshon begat Salma, and Salma begat Boaz.

questions.question: Who was the seventh son of Jesse as mentioned in 1 Chronicles 2:15?
questions.explanation: Verse 15 lists David as the seventh son of Jesse.

questions.question: How many sons did Zeruiah have according to 1 Chronicles 2:16?
questions.explanation: Zeruiah had three sons: Abishai, Joab, and Asahel as stated in verse 16.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 2:10 says Ram begat Amminadab, who begat Nahshon.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 clearly states Ram begat Amminadab and Amminadab begat Nahshon.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 2:34, Sheshan had many sons but no daughters.
questions.explanation: Verse 34 states Sheshan had no sons, but daughters.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Chronicles 2:21 tells us Hezron married the daughter of Machir when he was sixty years old.
questions.explanation: Verse 21 says Hezron married the daughter of Machir when he was threescore (sixty) years old.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Chronicles 2:22: 'Segub begat Jair, who had ______ cities in the land of Gilead.'
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states Jair had three and twenty cities in the land of Gilead.

questions.question: Who was the father of Tekoa according to 1 Chronicles 2:24?
questions.explanation: Verse 24 states that Ashur, father of Tekoa, was born to Abiah, Hezron's wife.

questions.question: Who was the concubine of Caleb that bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez according to 1 Chronicles 2:46?
questions.explanation: Verse 46 says Ephah, Caleb's concubine, bore Haran, Moza, and Gazez.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with family conflict and wondering about the importance of godly heritage. Based on 1 Chronicles 2, what biblical truth would you share about family and faith?
options: Our spiritual heritage and godly ancestors provide a foundation for faith and trust in God.
Family lineage is irrelevant to our spiritual walk with God.
Only the youngest children in a family carry spiritual blessings.
God does not care about family relationships in the Bible.
questions.correctAnswer: Our spiritual heritage and godly ancestors provide a foundation for faith and trust in God.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2 details the descendants of Judah and others, showing the importance of family lineage (verses 3-15). This teaches us to value our spiritual heritage and trust in God as our foundation (2:3-15, 10-16).

questions.question: How does the genealogy of David in 1 Chronicles 2:13-15 encourage perseverance through trials for a believer?
options: It shows that God works through imperfect families and difficult circumstances to fulfill His purposes.
It indicates that only perfect ancestors can lead to blessing.
It suggests that perseverance is unnecessary if one has a royal lineage.
It teaches that family history guarantees instant success.
questions.correctAnswer: It shows that God works through imperfect families and difficult circumstances to fulfill His purposes.
questions.explanation: David, the seventh son of Jesse, came from a complex family (2:13-15), highlighting God's grace in imperfect situations and teaching believers to persevere trusting in God's plan (2:3-17, 10-15).

questions.question: A believer wants to understand how to maintain integrity in daily life. What example from 1 Chronicles 2 could guide this believer?
options: Achar, called 'the troubler of Israel,' shows the consequences of transgressing God's commands.
All descendants of Judah were perfect and never sinned.
Only kings and priests need to have integrity.
Family lineage guarantees integrity without effort.
questions.correctAnswer: Achar, called 'the troubler of Israel,' shows the consequences of transgressing God's commands.
questions.explanation: Verse 7 mentions Achar, who transgressed and troubled Israel, warning believers about the importance of obedience and integrity in daily life (2:7, 17:6-7, 19).

questions.question: How does the passage about Hezron marrying at sixty and bearing Segub (1 Chronicles 2:21) teach about humility and God's timing?
options: God’s timing is perfect, and blessings can come at unexpected stages in life.
Blessings only come to the young and strong.
Marriage and children are not important after a certain age.
God does not intervene in personal life timing.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s timing is perfect, and blessings can come at unexpected stages in life.
questions.explanation: Hezron married and had a son at sixty, showing that God blesses according to His timing, encouraging believers to remain humble and trust God’s plan (2:21, Psalms 27:14, Ecclesiastes 3:1).

questions.question: Based on 1 Chronicles 2:10-12, what can believers learn about leadership and service in the church?
options: Leadership comes through godly ancestry and faithful service, as seen in Nahshon and Boaz.
Only those with royal blood are called to lead.
Leadership is based on popularity, not character.
Service is not important in leadership.
questions.correctAnswer: Leadership comes through godly ancestry and faithful service, as seen in Nahshon and Boaz.
questions.explanation: Nahshon, a prince, and Boaz, a man of faith, illustrate that leadership is linked to godly character and service (2:10-12, 2:9, Joshua 1:7-9).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 2:3, Er, the firstborn of Judah, was righteous and blessed by the Lord.
questions.explanation: Verse 3 states that Er was evil in the sight of the Lord and was slain by Him, teaching believers about the seriousness of obedience and holiness.

questions.question: How does the story of Tamar bearing Pharez and Zerah (1 Chronicles 2:4) teach about God's grace and faithfulness?
options: God brings blessing and continues His promises even through difficult or unconventional family situations.
God’s promises are limited to certain people.
questions.correctAnswer: God brings blessing and continues His promises even through difficult or unconventional family situations.
questions.explanation: Tamar, a daughter-in-law, bore Pharez and Zerah, showing God’s grace in continuing His covenant despite human failings (2:4, Genesis 38, Romans 5:20).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with temptation and failure. What encouragement does 1 Chronicles 2:16 provide about family support?
options: David’s sisters, Zeruiah and Abigail, and Zeruiah’s sons show the importance of family support and faithful relationships.
Temptation can only be overcome alone.
Family is irrelevant to spiritual growth.
Only men can support spiritual growth.
questions.correctAnswer: David’s sisters, Zeruiah and Abigail, and Zeruiah’s sons show the importance of family support and faithful relationships.
questions.explanation: Verse 16 names David's sisters and nephews, illustrating the role of family in providing encouragement and support (2:16, Ecclesiastes 4:9-12).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 2:34-35, what can believers learn about humility and contentment in God’s provision?
options: Sheshan gave his daughter to his servant Jarha, showing humility and trusting God’s provision in unexpected ways.
Believers must only marry within their social class.
God’s blessings depend on human status.
Servants cannot be part of God’s plan.
questions.correctAnswer: Sheshan gave his daughter to his servant Jarha, showing humility and trusting God’s provision in unexpected ways.
questions.explanation: The marriage of Sheshan’s daughter to his Egyptian servant Jarha (2:34-35) teaches believers to humbly accept God’s provision and trust His wisdom (James 4:6, Philippians 4:11-13).

questions.question: True or False: The genealogy in 1 Chronicles 2 teaches that God’s blessings and leadership roles are only given to those without any family failures.
questions.explanation: The chapter includes many examples of imperfect people and family struggles (e.g., Er, Achar), showing God’s grace in using flawed individuals (2:3, 2:7, 2:13-15).

questions.question: A believer wants to cultivate generosity and stewardship. Based on 1 Chronicles 2:22-23, what can be learned about stewardship from Jair’s possession of cities?
options: God entrusts resources and responsibilities to faithful individuals to manage and serve others.
Possessions are meant only for personal gain.
Stewardship is unimportant in spiritual life.
questions.correctAnswer: God entrusts resources and responsibilities to faithful individuals to manage and serve others.
questions.explanation: Jair had 23 cities, illustrating that God places stewardship responsibility on His people to use resources wisely for others’ benefit (2:22-23, Luke 16:10).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Chronicles 2:50, Caleb is described as the son of ________, the firstborn of Ephratah.
questions.explanation: Caleb is identified as the son of Hur, the firstborn of Ephratah, emphasizing the importance of knowing our spiritual heritage (2:19, 2:50).

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 2:55 teach us about humility and service in the church community?
options: The families of scribes dwelling at Jabez show the importance of faithful service and dedication in church life.
Only priests are important in the church.
Church roles depend on social status.
questions.correctAnswer: The families of scribes dwelling at Jabez show the importance of faithful service and dedication in church life.
questions.explanation: Verse 55 mentions scribes dwelling at Jabez, highlighting that faithful service, even in less prominent roles, is vital to the church community (2:55, Colossians 3:23).

questions.question: Based on 1 Chronicles 2:17, how can believers apply forgiveness and reconciliation in family relationships?
options: Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite, showing blended family reconciliation is possible.
Family members must always remain separate if from different backgrounds.
Forgiveness is unnecessary in family conflicts.
Only blood relatives can be forgiven.
questions.correctAnswer: Abigail bore Amasa, whose father was Jether the Ishmaelite, showing blended family reconciliation is possible.
questions.explanation: Abigail's marriage to Jether, an Ishmaelite, and their son Amasa (2:17) teaches believers to embrace forgiveness and reconciliation across cultural or family divides (Ephesians 4:32, Colossians 3:13).

questions.question: What biblical truth about faith and trust in God can be drawn from the detailed genealogies in 1 Chronicles 2?
options: God remains faithful through generations, and believers can trust His promises despite human failures.
Genealogy is only about human effort.
God’s promises are limited to one generation only.
We cannot trust God because human history is flawed.
questions.correctAnswer: God remains faithful through generations, and believers can trust His promises despite human failures.
questions.explanation: The genealogies show God’s ongoing covenant faithfulness through imperfect people (2:3-55), encouraging believers to trust God’s faithfulness (Genesis 17:7, Hebrews 13:5).

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 2.

questions.question: Which son of Judah was described as 'evil in the sight of the LORD' and was subsequently slain by God?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:3 states that Er, the firstborn of Judah, was evil in the sight of the LORD, and God slew him.

questions.question: Who were the two sons of Pharez mentioned in this chapter?
questions.explanation: According to 1 Chronicles 2:5, Pharez begat Hezron and Hamul.

questions.question: The genealogy of David is traced through which of the following sons of Jesse?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:13-15 lists Jesse’s sons in order, with David being the seventh son.

questions.question: Who was the father of Boaz, an important figure in the lineage of Jesus Christ according to the New Testament?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:11 states that Nahshon begat Salma, and Salma begat Boaz, linking Boaz directly in the genealogy.

questions.question: Which name listed in 1 Chronicles 2 is associated with the term 'the troubler of Israel' due to transgression in 'the thing accursed'?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:7 identifies Achar, son of Carmi, as the troubler of Israel who transgressed in the accursed thing.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The genealogy in 1 Chronicles 2 shows the significant role of the tribe of Judah. Which of the following best represents the number of sons Judah had, as mentioned in the chapter?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:4 notes that all the sons of Judah were five, including Er, Onan, Shelah, Pharez, and Zerah.

questions.question: Which of the following sets of names are the sons of Zerah, according to 1 Chronicles 2?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:6 lists the five sons of Zerah as Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara.

questions.question: True or False: The genealogy records that Caleb, the son of Hezron, had children with more than one woman, including concubines.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:18, 46, and 48 show Caleb had children with his wife Azubah and concubines Ephah and Maachah.

questions.question: What is the significance of Nahshon in the lineage of Judah as presented in this chapter, especially considering cross-biblical references to the Exodus narrative?
options: He was a prince and leader of the tribe of Judah
He was the first king of Israel
He was the father of King David
He was a prophet during the wilderness journey
questions.correctAnswer: He was a prince and leader of the tribe of Judah
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:10 identifies Nahshon as a prince of Judah; Exodus 6:25 and Numbers 1:7 confirm his leadership during the wilderness journey.

questions.question: Which name in 1 Chronicles 2 is linked with the founding of cities in the land of Gilead and is a son of Hezron?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:21-22 describes Segub, son of Hezron, who begat Jair, who had 23 cities in Gilead.

questions.question: Who was the father of Tekoa, as recorded in this chapter, and what does this indicate about the historical geography of Judah?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:24 shows Ashur, son of Hezron, as the father of Tekoa, highlighting Tekoa as a significant town in Judah's territory.

questions.question: The genealogy mentions Sheshan's daughters marrying an Egyptian servant named Jarha. What does this indicate about social or ethnic relationships in this period?
options: Intermarriage and integration of foreigners into Israelite society
Strict ethnic separation with no intermarriage
Complete exclusion of foreigners from tribal genealogies
questions.correctAnswer: Intermarriage and integration of foreigners into Israelite society
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:34-35 records Sheshan giving his daughter to Jarha, an Egyptian servant, showing social integration through marriage.

questions.question: Which son of Hezron married the daughter of Machir, father of Gilead, at an advanced age, symbolizing a covenantal linking of families and territories?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:21 records Hezron marrying the daughter of Machir when he was 60 years old, linking the families of Judah and Gilead.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 2, who was the father of Obed, an important ancestor of King David and ultimately Jesus Christ, as also highlighted in the New Testament genealogies?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:12 states that Boaz begat Obed, linking the Messianic line consistent with Matthew 1 and Luke 3 genealogies.

questions.question: Which of the following tribes is NOT listed among the sons of Israel in 1 Chronicles 2:1-2?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:1-2 lists the sons of Israel, including Naphtali, Gad, and Zebulun, but Ephraim is not mentioned in these verses (Joseph is included instead).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: Who were the first three sons of Judah mentioned in 1 Chronicles 2?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:3 states that Judah's sons were Er, Onan, and Shelah, born to the daughter of Shua. This genealogy highlights human failure (sin) and God's sovereign judgment, as Er was slain by the LORD (Genesis 38:7; Hebrews 11:37).

questions.question: Which son of Judah was described as evil in the sight of the LORD and was slain by Him?
questions.explanation: Verse 3 clearly identifies Er as the firstborn of Judah who was evil before the LORD and was slain by Him, demonstrating divine holiness and justice (Ecclesiastes 12:14; Romans 1:18).

questions.question: Who were the twin sons born to Tamar, Judah's daughter-in-law?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:4 names Tamar's sons as Pharez and Zerah, emphasizing God's providence in the messianic line through a non-ideal human situation (Matthew 1:3; Genesis 38:29).

questions.question: Who was the father of Boaz, an ancestor of David?
questions.explanation: Verse 11 states Nahshon begat Salma and Salma begat Boaz, connecting the messianic lineage and God's redemptive plan through Israel's history (Ruth 4:21-22; Matthew 1:5-6).

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 2, who was the father of Jesse, the father of David?
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 2:12 shows Boaz begat Obed, and Obed begat Jesse, establishing the Davidic line and God's covenant faithfulness (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Acts 13:22-23).

questions.question: Who among Jesse's sons was the seventh, who later became king?
questions.explanation: Verse 15 lists David as the seventh son of Jesse, chosen by God despite human expectations, illustrating the theme of divine election (1 Samuel 16:1-13; Acts 13:22).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the sons of Zerah mentioned in this chapter?
questions.explanation: Nahshon was of the line of Judah but descended from Ram (verses 10-11), while Zerah's sons were Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara (verse 6), showing distinct family branches (Numbers 1:7; Psalm 88:1).

questions.question: Who is described as 'the troubler of Israel' in this chapter?
questions.explanation: Verse 7 calls Achar the troubler of Israel who transgressed in the accursed thing, reflecting the reality of sin's disruptive impact on God's people (Joshua 7:1-26; Romans 5:12).

questions.question: Which city is associated with Ashur, the father of Tekoa?
questions.explanation: Verse 24 notes Hezron died in Calebephratah, and then his wife bore Ashur, father of Tekoa, indicating geographical and tribal settlements (2 Samuel 23:28; Amos 1:1).

questions.question: Which descendants of Jerahmeel married outside the Israelite lineage, according to this chapter?
options: Sheshan’s daughter married Jarha, an Egyptian servant
questions.correctAnswer: Sheshan’s daughter married Jarha, an Egyptian servant
questions.explanation: Verses 34-35 explain Sheshan had no sons but daughters; he gave his daughter to Jarha, his Egyptian servant, showing God's providence includes Gentile connections (Ruth 4:12,16; Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: Who was the father of the 23 cities in the land of Gilead?
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states Segub begat Jair, who had 23 cities in Gilead, demonstrating Israel's territorial inheritance and God's promise of land (Deuteronomy 12:20; Joshua 13:30-31).

questions.question: What is the significance of the genealogical record of David's family in this chapter?
options: It highlights God's sovereign election and covenant faithfulness
It focuses on the political power of Judah
It emphasizes the wealth of David's family
It documents the priestly lineage of Levi
questions.correctAnswer: It highlights God's sovereign election and covenant faithfulness
questions.explanation: The genealogy from Judah to David (verses 3-16) underscores God’s sovereign plan to bring forth the Messiah through a chosen family line, consistent with Old Testament covenants (2 Samuel 7:12-16; Romans 9:11-13; Hebrews 7:14).

questions.question: Which son of Caleb took a wife named Azubah and had sons named Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon?
questions.explanation: Verse 18 records Caleb son of Hezron begat children by Azubah and Jerioth, showing the expansion of tribal families (Numbers 13:6; Joshua 14:6-15).

questions.question: Who are the sons of Jesse mentioned in this chapter besides David?
options: Eliab, Abinadab, Shimma, Nethaneel, Raddai, Ozem
questions.correctAnswer: Eliab, Abinadab, Shimma, Nethaneel, Raddai, Ozem
questions.explanation: Verses 13-15 list Jesse’s sons as Eliab, Abinadab, Shimma, Nethaneel, Raddai, Ozem, and David, illustrating God's choice of the unexpected (1 Samuel 16:6-13; Romans 9:11-13).

questions.question: What is the theological implication of the repeated mention of family lines and descendants in 1 Chronicles 2?
options: It reveals God's providential preservation of His covenant people
It serves only as historical record without theological meaning
It focuses on the political alliances in Israel
It emphasizes human achievement and merit
questions.correctAnswer: It reveals God's providential preservation of His covenant people
questions.explanation: The genealogies emphasize God’s providence and faithfulness in preserving His covenant through generations (Psalm 105:8-11; Luke 3:23-38; Romans 11:1-2), showing the continuity of salvation history.
